SO,I was doing some junk at duna, using my space craft that has a nuke engine.

then after I had circularized the orbit on Duna, i turn the fuel and materials stuff up(the fuel can thingy)

I noticed that the ablator gauge went down like what. so, because of that, i went to ike instead.

same thing happened there ,then i landed, planted a flag, mess with the Kerbals, and do other stuff.

heres the problem:

wai is the ablator gauge going down and i have discovered some explosions on the Batt Man batteries(Z-400) the Nerv engine,

and the decoupler(under the heat shield) is overheating

sorry for shortened words.(its 11:16PM at my time)

and yes. im sleepy

Thanks in advance

**Edited <time datetime="2015-06-05T15:33:08Z" title="06/05/2015 03:33  PM" data-short="9 yr">June 5, 2015</time> by RandomRyan**
Your craft is overheating. Overheating causes ablator to ablate from ablative heat shield.
oh ok. so how do i not overheat the craft?

You have many options, some are easier and some are more practical.

For existing craft:

Try doing your burns at night side.

Try to expose your ship less to sun.

Do shorter burns.

Graze the highest part of an atmosphere to cool of a little (really little)

For new craft:

Do your own radiators from wings/panels. (They radiate heat but can also take more heat in)

Use solar panels. (They radiate heat but also take heat from other side.)

Have a heatsink (like an unusable tank of RCS).

And if your shield ablates during atmospheric entry, its normal. If its a lot, its time to slow down (if its an aerobrake, make your entry a little shallower)
oh so thats how. the craft exploded anyway. one went on EVA.

Sorry for your loss, the Nerv engine mysteriously overheats while its heating very cool propellant, so when youre going to use the nerv engine with a small craft without any advanced cooling mechanism, do short burns and keep an eye on the thermal info screen
